Context:
The text describes a diploma program offered by the college in the field of heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration (HVAC/R) for both residential and light commercial sectors. Here are some key facts extracted from the text:

- Students will gain solid skills and knowledge in designing, operating and maintaining environmental systems, specifically in HVAC/R.
- Students will develop practical skills through hands-on experience with various equipment and appliances.
- Students will become competent in soldering, wiring and electric control circuitry, as well as troubleshooting for HVAC and gas installations.
- Students will use computer-aided design software to assess building heating and cooling requirements and develop HVAC system drawings and specifications.
- The program follows industry-standard design practices for environmentally responsible and energy-efficient systems, as established by the Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute (HRAI), American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE), and the Canada Green Building Council.
- Students can challenge Gas Fitter 2 provincial qualification exam and obtain the certification if they are successful (75 per cent passing grade).
- Students will be prepared for various positions in the HVAC field, including installing, maintaining and repairing heating, air conditioning and refrigeration systems for commercial and residential buildings.
- Students can challenge Ontario Ministry of Consumer Affairs and Housing, HVAC House exam to obtain "Building Code Identification Number" (BCIN) if they are successful (75 per cent passing grade).
- The program has a mandatory requirement for students to complete semester 2 in the summer to continue into semester 3 in the fall.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technician Program T160 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The George Brown College offers a diploma program in HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) technology. Students will be prepared for various positions in the HVAC field, including installation, maintenance, repair of heating, air conditioning, and refrigeration systems for commercial and residential buildings. Other employment opportunities include sales, system balancing, cost-estimating for projects, and self-employment with a Gas Fitter 2 certification.

The program consists of four semesters:

Semester 1:
- HVAC 1001: Refrigeration Theory I
- HVAC 1006: Electrical Fundamentals for HVAC
- HVAC 1018: Gas Technician III
- GSCI 1022: Building Science and the Environment
- MATH 1145: Math for HVAC 1
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Semester 2:
- HVAC 1003: Refrigeration Laboratory Applications
- HVAC 1008: Electrical Circuit Analysis for HVAC
- HVAC 1016: Gas Technician II (Part A)
- HVAC 1022: Understanding Construction Drawings
- HVAC 2003: Refrigeration Theory II
- MATH 1155: Math for HVAC 2
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- HVAC 1017: Gas Technician II (Part B)
- HVAC 2001: Residential HVAC System Design
- HVAC 2012: Air Conditioning Theory
- HVAC 2014: Building Code for HVAC
- PORT 1001: Portfolio
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 4:
- HVAC 1021: Gas Technician II (Part C)
- HVAC 2006: Air Conditioning Laboratory Applications
- HVAC 2013: HVAC Computer Applications
- COMM 1113: Professional Communications for Building Technologies
- GNED: General Education Elective

Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000. This course does not count as a course required for graduation and will incur an additional charge.

General Education Electives are part of the program, but no specific courses were mentioned. The graduate learning outcomes are not listed in the text.

Context:
The text provides information about a program offered at George Brown College, specifically in the field of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning. Here are the key facts extracted from the text:

1. Program name: The text does not explicitly state the name of the program, but it can be inferred from the context that it is related to Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning.
2. General Education Electives: Students will take general education elective courses as part of their program.
3. Detailed course outlines: The text does not mention detailed course outlines.
4. Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate of the program is expected to be able to relate effectively with supervisors, coworkers and customers; work safely in accordance with all applicable acts, regulations, legislation and codes; use tools and equipment safely and properly; solve math and applied science problems required for installation and maintenance; prepare and interpret drawings; install, service and troubleshoot heating, refrigeration, air conditioning systems and associated components; and develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development.
5. Tuition & Fees: Domestic tuition is $3,904 for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2022. International tuition is $17,531 for the same period starting in Fall 2023. Additional costs are listed but not specified.
6. Financial Assistance: The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
7. Admission Requirements: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, including grade 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 math (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to meet the credit requirements.

Therefore, the extracted information is:

Program Name: Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning
General Education Electives: Yes
Learning Outcomes: Relate effectively with supervisors, coworkers and customers; Work safely in accordance with all applicable acts, regulations, legislation and codes; Use tools and equipment safely and properly; Solve math and applied science problems required for installation and maintenance; Prepare and interpret drawings; Install, service and troubleshoot heating, refrigeration, air conditioning systems and associated components; Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development
Tuition & Fees: Domestic - $3,904 (Fall 2022), International - $17,531 (Fall 2023)
Financial Assistance: OSAP funding for eligible applicants
Admission Requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent; grade 12 English (C or U); either grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 math (C or U); or mature student status with Admissions Assessment or upgrading for English and math credit requirements.
